video.title: Learn Tailwind CSS – Course for Beginners
video.description:
This course will give you a full introduction into all of the core concepts of Tailwind CSS — it will also provide details on every features that provides Tailwindcss.

Course from @codewithguillaume .

⭐️ Contents ⭐️
⌨️ (0:00:00) Introduction
⌨️ (0:02:36) Setup
⌨️ (0:17:01) Colors
⌨️ (0:29:11) Customization
⌨️ (0:42:11) Typography
⌨️ (1:05:21) Spaces & sizes
⌨️ (1:29:36) Flex
⌨️ (1:51:46) Grids
⌨️ (2:12:48) Layouts
⌨️ (2:37:49) Borders
⌨️ (2:45:41) Effects & filters
⌨️ (2:57:33) Animations
⌨️ (3:08:28) Design System
⌨️ (3:56:31) Core concepts
⌨️ (4:05:26) Dark mode

🎉 Thanks to our Champion and Sponsor supporters:
👾 Nattira Maneerat
👾 Heather Wcislo
👾 Serhiy Kalinets
👾 Erdeniz Unvan
👾 Justin Hual
👾 Agustín Kussrow
👾 Otis Morgan

--

Learn to code for free and get a developer job: https://www.freecodecamp.org

Read hundreds of articles on programming: https://freecodecamp.org/news

topLevelComment.text:

topLevelComment.author: nadav ben simon
topLevelComment.text: The main problem with those libraries that offer free css is that what they offer is easy to build in css and could replicate in less than 5 minutes,but if you want the complex and the hard to do styling and animations then you have to pay money or do it yourself .the other problem they have is that they stack css classes in top of each other so instead your html element havi g one class with one or 2 selectors to work with it now has 10 classes with 20 different selectors to work with that damage performance for something that could be done in 5 minutes

topLevelComment.author: Dink Thifferently
topLevelComment.text: To new developers.... please learn regular CSS as well as you can FIRST before you use things like Tailwind. You'll be a better dev for it. (and you'll be a more "hire-able" developer as an employee since most companies still use CSS or SCSS)

topLevelComment.author: Janaka de Silva
topLevelComment.text:
Great content thanks @codewithguillaume it was just a few days ago I got a new framework to work on so it's already using tailwind and here your course is on youtube. I have a question at 3:15:44 

Let's say I'm writing a different colour for H1 in responsive mode. What are the options I have to write the responsive style? 

1-Using standard media queries. 2-Use the tailwind class at the same spot and write the responsive style. 3-Or any other option such as making another code block just to keep the responsive code separate 4-Tailwind already have a different approach for it.

#codewithguillaume

replies.text: @Code with Guillaume Thanks :D maybe I can use some separation to make the visibility/readability ...

topLevelComment.author: zzzyyyxxx
topLevelComment.text: Thanks for the tutorial but not sure why people should use Tailwind nowadays instead of learning CSS well. I used Tailwind a lot at work and now I've grown to dislike it, it's easy to write, sure, but if you're trying to go back and edit anything, it's extremely annoying, like a "write-only" language like Perl. Just learn CSS well and use that.

replies.author: Dink Thifferently
replies.text:
@chips hit You really should build a good "foundation" for your development skills. The foundation of HTML, CSS, and Javascript. Get as good as you can in all 3. Only then should you branch out with CSS and JS frameworks. 

Especially if your goal is to be an employable developer. If you only can style stuff with Tailwind, but your job is using regular CSS or SCSS, then you're screwed. And if Tailwind eventually isn't the hot new thing anymore (some other CSS framework is) then that's not good either. And even when you only use Tailwind, it's still good to know what it's doing behind the scenes (for debugging)

replies.author: João Victor Schoen
chips hit
replies.text: Always if you care to elaborate: Is it still worth to learn HTML/CSS in 2023? With all these sites offering 0 to low code website building? I personally think its 50/50. But would like to hear the opinion of somebody who maybe is a professional ? (If you work with css as you mentioned) :)
